description: This beautiful gothic-style cathedral is one of the city's most prominent landmarks.

reviews.title: Neo Gothic Cathedral
text: St Michael's Cathedral is the Roman Catholic Cathedral in Toronto, it was completed in 1848 with the stained glass windows being added several years later.

reviews.title: Stunning stained glass window
text: The catholic cathedral is very close to Dundas square. It has the most stunning stained glass window just above the equally impressive alter. A very calming place to wander around

reviews.title: St Michaels Catholic Cathedral
text: St Michaels Catholic Cathedral is a lovely church. It dates back to the mid-1800s. If you are in Downtown Toronto it's worth stopping by for a look at this beautiful building.

reviews.title: Beautifully constructed building.
text: The architecture in this building is phenomenal. The pipe organ is pretty cool. Don’t miss that. There is sacred silence practiced.

reviews.title: Remarkable Cathedral, Solemn Easter Services
text: I had attended the Holy Thursday services (Washing of the Feet) for probably 25 consecutive years—until COVID-19 made it impossible in 2020. After a hiatus of 3 years, I again had the privilege to personally participate in this very solemn celebration on April 6, 2023—and it was my first visit to the Cathedral in 4 years.
There were many ushers, assisting visitors to find a seat. St. Michael’s Choir School was, as always, extraordinary.

I was still impressed by the huge renovations which had taken place not so long ago. The beautiful stained glass windows were splendid after the renovations. For the first time I was able to go up and visit the totally rebuilt balcony and admire the view of the cathedral from up there.

reviews.title: Beautiful House of Worship
text: Persons interested in church architecture, religion, and art would enjoy visiting St. Michael's Cathedral Basilica in Toronto.  This is a beautiful church and I was happy to be able to visit it.

reviews.title: Beautiful
text: We enjoyed taking a few moments of rest and prayer in the basilica. It was a peaceful and beautiful space in which to seek retreat.

reviews.title: Beautiful Cathedral
text: We lived in Toronto for two years and attended mass every Sunday at St Michael's Cardinal Collins is such a special priest, we watched Sunday mass every week during COVID.

reviews.title: Beautiful Cathedral
text: Beautiful Cathedral Church in the English Gothic Revival Style, built in 1848.  This beautiful building is full of character and detail amongst plain glass and flat stone and composite buildings surrounding it.  Its remarkable both in and out.

reviews.title: Rude Female Usher
text: Filipina usher at 5:00 PM Sunday Mass behaves like a rude prison warden.  She rudely compels people to get up and leave certain pews and orders them to move to other pews. She does not keep the 6-foot social distance when talking to people, but comes within 12 inches of one's face.  She yells at people who have no masks on in spite of being told that they have exemption for medical reasons under Sec. 2 (a) 2 of Bylaw 541-2020.  This usher is very arrogant.  Such a person ruins the sacredness of the church.

reviews.title: Serene Solice in a Sea of Stress
text: With most of the shopping done for back to school, we decided to walk to St Michael's cathedral for evening mass. There is confession available between 4:15-4:45. Be sure to line up early as the priest may not be able to reach everyone before he needs to prepare for Sunday service at 5pm. The evening service does not have the boys choir and instead is led by a cantor. The gothic style is very conducive for meditating, and as you admire stained glass windows and the vaulted ceilings, you can glimpse the bishop's hat, hung way above the alter, attributable to the 1st bishop, Michael Power.

reviews.title: Beautiful Glass Stained Windows
text: This is the very first time I went to hear mass at the seat of the Roman Catholic church in Toronto. It is very near Eaton Centre and Yonge street so I decided  to hear the 5:30 mass before attending a musicale at the nearby Ed Mirvish Theatre in Victoria Street .

The cathedral is just beside the St Michael Hospital that you can see hospital patients even those in wheelchairs hearing mass. I was mesmerized by the numerous glass stained windows that enveloped the churched including that of the main altar. It is a very quiet church and hearing mass here is so solemn you can hear a pin drop.
Would definitely make this a go to church whenever I am in downtown.

reviews.title: construction of the cathedral
text: Experience the cathedral and enjoy the interior while keeping in mind the craftsmanship of the work along with considering the years it was constructed and the tools that were available at the time of construction.

reviews.title: Beautiful Mass and Choir
text: So to those who are particular with the music style during mass, this church provides many weekly masses with various choirs. I attended the weekly saturday vigil mass whereby the choir was a bunch of school boys from the St Michael's Choir School and they were pretty good. I was lucky enough to attend this mass as it was their last singing before summer break. It was my first ever mass with such choir as I am from Malaysia, totally dumbfounded as it was acapella.
p/s: taking of photographs is strictly prohibited during mass

reviews.title: A statement about its eternal architectural style. A comparison with cathedrals in Europe for external location.
text: I know this area of downtown Toronto as I have walked through the streets on my way to several destinations. I have walked past the basilica and I will say that it is a large church well worth your time to see and visit. My familiarity with Young and surrounding streets is good enough to qualify me to say something about the church. Going back to earlier parts of this century I have watched renovations take place. I am not a member of the church's group of worshipers. I will not comment about the interior. I like to see how older looking churches fit into the modern urban landscape that includes taller buildings and sky scrapers. I like to see how these older looking buildings continue to hold their attraction for drawing visitors to see them. I do not pass up a chance to explore on foot downtown Toronto each time I am there. So I walked along the streets. I knew about Church street from finding it once or twice further up north near the Bloor Street interchange with Young. But here it was near the downtown area of Toronto -closer to areas that I had seen just by being close the U of T region and I was curious to know how it measures up with the cathedrals I had seen in Europe. So I am looking at the exterior. There is much to be said about how the construction and architectural style of the cathedral makes the entire church fit in the urban landscape that surrounds it. The contrast in the function and purposes of the surrounding buildings is another issue. Banks and financial centers and commercial retail stores offer more than just a functional contrast with cathedrals. I did find it to be beautiful as a principal landmark for the city. Yes, it looks impressive in this location. I have never worshipped there but I was interested during my walking tours of downtown Toronto in 2016 and before to look at this structure from the standpoint of how it fits in the urban landscape. I had been walking in this part of Toronto in earlier years so I was familiar with street names and building locations. Yes, I did make comparisons with famous cathedrals that I had seen in many European cities. My interest was in its external architectural style. Was it out of place today? In many ways downtown regions need a variety of building styles. I did go back more than three times to see it from different vantage points. I did walk along King Street and Queen Street and I knew where Adelaide Street was in relation to Young Street. Many of my observations are coming together to be close to forming a conclusion about this question. Did I see or look for flying buttresses? How exact were my comparisons with cathedral of European cities? Does a cathedral like this one alway have to be located in a large city? An element of city planning was involved in my thinking. The age of Toronto compared with much older european cities was also a factor for me to consider. Certain question remain to be answered. Tell me what you think. It might not be fair to compare this basilica with Chartres or the large church in Cologne or Notre Dame in Paris by looking only at their external appearance and location.

reviews.title: Newly renovated St. Michael's Cathedral
text: Attended a service at the Cathedral celebrating the 175 years of the Archdiocese of Toronto.  The Cathedral looks impressive with its newly restored stained glass images. The basement is nicely done with the cript of the first archbishop of Toronto Micheal Power.

reviews.title: A most beautiful church
text: Went here for Saturday Mass. Being wheelchair-bound, access was easy with the ramp at the front entrance. The inside of the church was so beautiful. Before Mass all we did was gawk around the entire church as there was so much to see. People were friendly and helpful. Never knew we had an accent until we were told so by the locals. It was nice that it was only a short distance from our downtown hotel. The sound system was excellent as we could easily hear the entire Mass. Glad we came early to get a seat as the church was full.

reviews.title: Renewal at St. Michaels Cathedral
text: My family and I have worshipped at St. Michaels many timers over the years. The building has been renovated recently and looks fantastic, new yet the same original milestone. The Pastors are very approachable and the interior of The Cathedral is contemplative and welcoming. Sitting out side enjoying the grounds or seeking quiet this is one of Toronto's landmark places to visit.

reviews.title: Stunning
text: Stunning ...attended Christmas eve mass...packed...but they have monitors so able to see. No wifi....so getting Uber back to hotel very problematic. ...especially with a 3 year old.

reviews.title: When the scaffolding moves....
text: A great deal of restoration has been underway for many months and will continue for awhile yet. But kudos that one of Torontos oldest buildings is being restored.

reviews.title: Beautiful Church
text: Went to early mass before a day of site seeing. Beautiful stained glass windows and worth a visit. Gothic style built in 1847.

reviews.title: Passing By Toronto
text: My wife and I saw this listed on Trip Advisor so we decided to stop. What an interesting place! We spent a couple hours walking though the Cathedral and looking at all the information regarding the stained glass windows and other items.  The place had just finished an extensive refurbishment and it showed. We wish we could have seen more detailed pics of the Church prior to all the rehab work. The history is very interesting and certainly helps provide some perspective to this incredible building. Even though it’s in the heart of the downtown area, parking was easy. It’s a little pricey but after all we’re in a major metropolitan area. The outside landscaping was in the process of being completed so at first glance, it looks as if the rehab is incomplete. Not so, as the inside is completely finished.

reviews.title: Very Solemn Church
text: St Michael is awesome especially with the new renovations. It has a comfortable seats and the service is alive and sometimes televised especially when the Toronto Mayor is joining the service. It is a busy church though as it is close to the eaton's center so most shoppers go to the mass first before going shopping.

reviews.title: St Michael's Cathedral
text: This is a must see place for Toronto residents and tourists. I have been living in Toronto for almost thirty years but this is just my second time to go there. The first visit was in 2003. The cathedral was renovated. There is still construction going on so picture taking in front of the cathedral is not good at this time but the inside architecture of this church is really amazing. Problem is visitors can not take pictures inside.

reviews.title: Lovely place to worship
text: A friend and I were in town for a concert at Massey Hall, and since were there on a Sunday morning, I searched nearby churches and found the gorgeous St. Michael's.

St. Michael's so reminded me of my old Hungarian church in Cleveland that was sold off in recent years to "pay bills" for the diocese, but that's a different story.  The simple yet intricate worship space with a sky blue base really brought me home.  I was also a little wistful with kneelers (!), and passing of the basket.  And the stained glass is something to look at even if you aren't there for mass.  Just beautiful and serene and very European.

The worshippers at Sunday morning 8am mass looked like a mix of regulars and visitors, not overly friendly, but friendly enough.  Mass was not long, but also not rushed, and while Father didn't bring us the message of the Homily with any unique or personal stories, he communicated his message.

I was actually shocked at the bulletin.  I thought it was a little light.  I imagined a church in a neighborhood like this (we found heroine needles across the street at an abandoned building on the sidewalk) would have a long list of different community services and support available, but perhaps I overlooked some other bulletin boards of information.
I'm already planning on another trip up to Toronto possibly this summer, and will make it a point to stay in the same neighborhood and stop by for mass again.

reviews.title: Beautiful place to visit, worship and meditate but problems with accessibility to the restrooms!.
text: One disappointment is that Cathedral has no fully accessible washrooms. There are stairs leading to the basement to both men and women washrooms. Unfortunately, for us others who need barrier-free access to the washrooms, we have to rely, (to search for) security person who will than let us in one small elevator, we exit half floor and than we are let in to the other tiny elevator to finally arrive in the front of the big restroom door, which is NOT accessible. It doesn't even have push button! With my walker and shortness of breath it is definitely struggle to get in and out,by pushing/pulling heavy doors - it certainly causes me a lot of hardship! Than again I must wait for security person to come and let me up in the elevators to return to the Cathedral. Wheelchair or even baby stroller will NOT fit in those two small elevators. It is very disappointing that it has not been better designed for worshipers, as myself & visitors with disabilities and those who need barrier free access!

reviews.title: Beautiful!
text: Attended the noon mass. It was lovely. The church is beautiful. Love the stained glass windows as the afternoon light shone through them.

reviews.title: Unfinished appearance
text: Fists visit since the extensive renovation and like every work of art brought back to the original colours, the large basilica seems almost fake with the light walls cement coloured and the vibrant blue and pink of the ceiling and upper walls. Something is still missing to gain the previous warmth, but the additions of meeting places, elevators etc.. will make for a better Parish life

reviews.title: Beautiful Catholic Cathedral
text: We visited St. Michael's and were very impressed by the size and location of the cathedral.  It was located near the center of the city. It really is a beautiful peaceful place to visit.

reviews.title: Beautiful, small catherdal church
text: I was really lucky to go into the church as one of the soloist's from the choir school across the road was practicing, it was magical. Lovely altar and stain glass windows, a little gem in a busy city. My friends had never been in a catholic church before and found it very beautiful.

reviews.title: Solemn Experience
text: Attended Ash Wednesday mass . Never realised the many Catholics joining the activity. Some parishioners can’t find seats. But it was solemn . Good acoustic sound coverage . Noticed how beautiful the Cathedral was. Fine architectural design. For me it was one landmark in the city. Seeing sanitizer dispensers means they are taking precautions as well .

reviews.title: Beautiful Cathedral
text: We attended mass at noon on a Sunday with the Boys choir.  It was a lovely spiritual experience. The music was excellent as was the mass and homily. We were taken with the beauty of the architecture and stained glass windows.  The location is great in the center of Toronto.  Easily accesible from downtown hotels for visitors.

reviews.title: Welcoming place
text: Never has a church given me such deep thought with its atmosphere of silence and respect. Beautiful architecture and beautiful interior decoration with splendid stained glass windows. The mass was very good with a homily done very well by the priest. It is not very easy to attend Mass in a language other than ours, but it is always an interesting experience.

reviews.title: Lovely Cathedral but problem with accessible washrooms.
text: Love to come to mass and pray. Trouble is that getting to washroom is too complicated. Finding the security person to unlock the first elevator,then getting off to walk to another elevator; finally struggling to open the heavy washroom doors, just way too difficult!! Esp. if coming with baby strollers, walker like myself, wheelchairs which might not even fit into small elevators. Washroom are also locked beetwen masses...security reasons.Very disappointed since I would love to visit more often and spend some quiet prayerful time.

reviews.title: Great old cathedral
text: I attended 10am mass one Sunday. It’s easily found on Church St (appropriately) and it’s a huge gothic style cathedral. Inside the stained glass is amazing as is the organ with 15 or so horns protruding from the wall. The seats and kneelers were well padded and extremely comfortable. The sermon was good too. Worth a visit.

reviews.title: Beautiful Basilica!
text: We attended the 12 noon Sunday Mass and had the pleasure of hearing the St. Michael’s Senior Boys Choir lead the singing. Amazing voices! The Church is a stunning gothic style!

reviews.title: Picturesque Cathedral
text: An gothic-style Catholic Basilica on Bond street across the street from St Michael’s hospital. Very nice interior with its elegant columns holding up the wooden beamed ceiling. It is flanked by beautiful stained glass windows and the imposing windows behind the main altar. Very nice and peaceful. Looks similar from the outside to St James Anglican Cathedral which is a few blocks away but IMO St Michael’s interior is a bit more picturesque.

reviews.title: Beautiful and Spectacular
text: This is an old glorious cathedral worthy of any around the world. There is such rich paintings carvings sculptures and architecture inside and out. Come see this side of Toronto Canada!!!

reviews.title: finally (almost) completed renovation
text: after an extensive renovation, the inside is now magnificent, in colours and comfort (AC cranked too high) with new speakers and energy efficient lights. the area under the church has now a large chapel and good public facilities. the outside is still being completed, but mainly the pavement in front of the main entrance, while before was covering the facade and was a bit of difficult access, it will now be wide open and easily accessible

reviews.title: Beautiful
text: We were in Toronto on a weekend and was looking for a Church near our hotel to attend Mass. The Cathedral was just a few blocks away so we attend 5 P.M. Mass on Saturday. We felt right at home and loved the beautiful surroundings. It was just breath taking.
